title: Can the Coronavirus (COVID 19) travel through the wind? - Quora

response.answer_text: I expect many widely promulgated beliefs about COVID-19 to bite the dust before too long, among them the two-metre danger zone. Hate anecdotal evidence? Here’s my take on windborne transmission, but it’s not even evidence, it’s just an anecdote. I was carefully avoiding coronavirus trouble since January. Then on St Patrick’s Day I biked over to the liquor store after supper. Out of would-be prudence I waited till just before closing time, expecting the store to be emptier. There was a homeless man sitting in the doorway of a closed cafe adjacent to the store around four or five metres away from the locking ring where I got off my bike. As I got the lock out of my bag, a store employee appeared at the door and locked it, a couple of minutes early. Dismayed, I began putting my lock back in the bag just as the guy sitting down began coughing his lungs out. Seldom have I wanted to get out of anywhere as fast, which was exactly why I clumsily dumped all kinds of ID and other cards out of my bag onto the sidewalk. It must have taken me ten seconds to pick them all up, but it of course seemed like thirty. All the while the guy hacked as loudly and as unrestrainedly as possible, not covering his mouth. He was pale, sweaty, and sick-looking. The wind was moving slightly, about as much as the air conditioning in a mall. It seemed to be drifting from the direction of the sick guy. It then occurred to me that he’d been sitting there coughing for hours, including right up till the moment I appeared. I tried to hold my breath but couldn’t avoid inhaling just as I got my feet on the pedals. I shot the guy a dirty look and sped off to a different store. Sure enough, three days later I felt a fever come over me as I lounged at home doing very little. Other symptoms followed, and I’m still battling the illness weeks later. To my shame, I had a two-pack of good 3M masks at home, purchased last fall for wearing while using my circular saw. It was still sealed, as I was waiting for the confirmed cases in my city to pass one in 100,000 before wearing them. I haven’t often felt like such a dumbass. Maybe it’s anecdotal evidence after all. Who can say?

Ashley Owens asks if COVID-19 can transfer through the wind, which should be asked by everyone. No one seems to question a six-foot rule, but that is based on air transmission of a tiny virus, which must be suspended in liquid from cough or sneeze. More recently the concern escalated enough to recommend face covering, and another concern about a “pink eye” noted in about 30% of patients. Basically it is in the air. Wind is just moving air, which is how it gets to us. Water is not just a stream, spray, mist, or aerosol, it gets as small as a molecule of H2O. That molecule is a gas. The smallest water can get as liquid as we know it is a six molecule hexamer. It’s size is about 0.5 nanometers, which happens to be about the size of the smallest virus. When it is cold outside you see your breath, which is the saturated warm air from your lungs condensing in the cold air. This condensation happens when we don’t see it in room air, and that can contain virus, carried in the wind. Room air is not still, it is constantly stirred up, more with HVAC heating and in airplanes, which exchanges air 5-6 times an hour. Wind should be a concern and then some. Whenever you smell anything, remember that there is a molecule that landed inside your nose. The dry virus physically looks like a pollen particle, but smaller by magniturdes and more likely to stay aerodynamically suspended in the wind

Thank you, my friend, for asking me to reply to this extremely precise question. Good Evening. The National Institute of Health has recommended all people wear a mask, when entering any building open to the public. The reason for this health advisory is understandable. The Covid-19 virus is almost exclusively an airborne virus. In an enclosed building, were we to inhale sufficient quantities of the coronavirus antigen, we would ourselves, become infected. We must also be mindful Italian doctors detected viable antigens of the virus, in an enclosed room of an infected patient, who was only…breathing…thirty (30) feet away from the patient. Here, in 6the United States, we were able to capture viable antigens of the coronavirus…sixteen and a half (16 1/2) feet from a patient who wasn’t coughing, or sneezing…just breathing. However, you asked about “windy” conditions. I believe, should we observe social distancing (two meters/six feet), from any person, simply because we are in an “open air” setting, instead of an enclosed building, we run minimal chance of being infected…even with airborne antigens. If we are six feet apart from another person, and it’s windy enough to blow the sugar right out of a cup of coffee…I think it would be impossible for us to become infected. I hope you remain healthy, my friend, and enjoy a pleasant Evening.

Over short distances (measured in meters): YES. Over long distances (measured in kilometers): NO. It is airborne. It lingers in the air. In winter much longer than in summer. Wind influences the local air flow so wind can influence who gets infected on the local level. I absolutely cannot imagine that it is stable enough to travel from village to town or from city to city through the wind (but unless someone measures that we cannot be entirely sure). I am really sure, however, that the authors of the following paper made a huge mistake by publishing a WRONG POSTULATE (luckily they don’t claim that it is true, just a postulate) that viruses even can travel across oceans by wind (it’s about the flu virus but if they were right, it could be applied to the Covid-19 virus, too): Impact of atmospheric dispersion and transport of viral aerosols on the epidemiology of influenza - PubMed They overlooked the fact that viruses can have a seasonal effect which comprises BOTH, the infectivity AND the virulence/deadliness (IFR) of a virus and hence can “pop up” out of “nowhere” when it gets cold. See Florian Neubauer's answer to Will there be another COVID outbreak in December? for details.

If it is a windy day and a person in front of you were to sneeze or cough and you are literally right next to them then yes their bodily fluids can travel through the wind and land on you. That is the reason for social distancing. It is to provide enough space between you and someone else if they cough or sneeze. It isn't an air born virus that lingers on the air like the measles virus that can. It has to have biomatter from an infected human to spread. Once the biomatter dries out it dies.

Sort of but to be clear coronavirus isn't just flying around everywhere. The virus can spread from coughing up large or tiny droplets of mucus with the virus in them. You inhale these droplets and the virus spreads to you. The virus can also be couched up onto countertops, or onto hands, then it can move to an uninfected person when they touch these things and then touch their face. So in a sense it can be airborne but generally only near an infected person.

Yes, but it is not likely to deliver enough of the virus to make someone sick. The wind would disperse the virus to harmless quantities and hasten its debilitation. If you would be near a person who sneezes or coughs in your direction, without having the mouth covered, as the wind blows toward you then that would be unfortunate. But the farther the wind would blow airborne virus particles the more disperse they will become.

Yes, it’s the same as a cough or sneeze. The virus gets expelled and is then subject to whatever air movement there is. Even walking through the particles, can make them sway to and fro. But with a wind, that distributes them faster and in a larger area (as most wind is kept outside), so you are slightly safer outside rather than inside. Don’t stand by your neighbors fence and sneeze on their dog, but you can enjoy some fresh air with no guilt.

Coronavirus travels through water droplets, so it will float in the wind as far as the wind takes it. However, it is very unlikely that you will catch it when it is flying around in the wind. The water droplets / particles have to settle down in your nose or mouth for the virus to be able to infect you and multiply. That is why mask mandates are enforced in closed spaces and outside in the open only when you are in a crowded place where distancing cannot be ensured.

No, at least not to a very large extent. Viruses are tiny, and I mean really tiny. If one of the hairs on your head had the thickness of a football field, the coronavirus would be the size of a quarter. Because of this, the wind would probably move the virus to some extent, but not very far, considering the virus’s size and 2–3-day lifespan. Hope this helps!

No and yes both. Cause- For the ans no: Corona can not travel or spread out by air. Because this is a virus and they have no living properties outside the host.For the ans yes: respiratory droplet can travel by wind. And respiratory droplet can carry Corona virus. For this, minimum 3 feet or 1 meter distance maintain is must for all and use mask to inhibit going inside respiratory droplet via eye, nose, and mouth.

response.answer_text: Yes, but unless you are close to an infected person, the wind would disperse and dilute the virus concentration so you would be less likely to become ill. If you remain downwind from an infected person for a while, the cumulative effect would be greater. This is why they recommend not running right behind someone, especially if the are not masked.

YES, But… Infections have shown that airflow in restaurants can cause infections beyond the usual 2 meters/6 feet. However in the open air the virus would be quickly dispersed to the point of harmlessness, unless you were just upwind of a large number of infectious people. Additionally, in daytime the virus would also be attacked by UVB in the sunlight. In conclusion, on a breezy day you should exercise common sense and allow extra social distancing (double) upwind where possible, but otherwise generally don’t worry about wind transmission.

In theory yes. In practise wind disperses it. Many people are missing that WHO has consistently repeated there is no airborne transmission in the community. In plain English you dont get it outdoors! Close contact inside and from surfaces then touching your face. Hence wash your hands don’t touch your face keep distance

Of course, it can be wafted along by the wind. However, the same wind has a tendency to dilute the viruses that it is carrying and chances are that if you do happen to encounter one brought to you by the wind you will not be subject to a large enough viral load to contract the disease.

Yes. It’s mostly spread through droplets that can be spread through the wind. However, it has a limited lifespan outside of a host body. The article below explains (SARS-CoV2 is yet another name for Covid-19 or novel Coronavirus). Aerosol and Surface Stability of SARS-CoV-2 as Compared with SARS-CoV-1 | NEJM

It is spread by droplets. Without any force applied to them, they don’t travel on their own, they just fall onto any surfaces below them, but they can be picked by the wind and carried as far as the wind can take them.

Yes, COVID-19 can travel through the wind. It is spread through the mist of mucous and saliva infected people exhale when they cough, sneeze, or breathe. The recommended space for social distancing is based on the expected spread of the aerosol from a sneeze in still air. Air movement will allow it to spread a bit farther, but will also dissipate it more quickly.

‘….Through the wind’ οr by the wind? The 6-foot/2-meter ‘social distancing’ recommendation is based on the fact that the sputum/aerosol containing the virus from a sneeze or cough COULD travel that distance before dispersing. Wind would cause this dispersal to occur faster.

response.answer_text: It has been shown to be airborne. In close contact for prolonged periods of exposure, it is transmissible but out in the open air and even among others for relatively brief periods, it is significantly less transmissible.
Yes. Droplets that come from coughing or sneezing can remain airborne for a short distance - less that 6 feet - hence the suggestion for social distancing.
I’m sure it can but it would be dispersed so quickly you wouldn’t need to worry about it. It doesn’t travel the world on the wind, it travels on people.
Yes and no. As an aerosol, Corona-virus can be readily spread by air currents and of course wind. However, a strong wind will dissipate the viral load that will reach a possible infectee.
I think it has been proven that it could, for short distances, like someone huffing & puffing upwind as they jog by you. So wear a mask.
Several months ago the CDC said covid-19 could attach itself to air pollution particles and even the ocean spray. Next they will say it can be passed by farts.
Of course. Keep in mind that, as a virion does so it quickly becomes so much less likely to ever find a host.
The aerosolized viral particles will move as fast as the air is moving! If it is windy they will move faster and farther!
Yes. Fortunately, it also spreads out - and therefore dilutes - the virus in its dispersion.
Of course ! That is why its exact range is never clear, and why you should always stay upwind from other people when possible .
